subject: Creativity
title: Chekhov's Gun: Every Detail Must Fire
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Chekhov's Gun: Every Detail Must Fire.

hook.text: If a gun hangs on the wall in Act 1, it must fire by Act 3. Otherwise, remove it. That's Chekhov's Gun.

buildup.text: Anton Chekhov argued that every element in a story must serve a purpose. Irrelevant details dilute narrative tension.

discovery.text: This principle teaches economy: readers unconsciously track every detail.

twist.text: Alfred Hitchcock used 'red herrings' â€” deliberate violations of Chekhov's Gun â€” to misdirect audiences in thrillers.

climax.text: In Breaking Bad, almost every seemingly insignificant detail pays off episodes or seasons later â€” masterful gun-firing.

punchline.text: Every word is a promise to the reader. Great writers keep every promise.

quiz.question: What does Chekhov's Gun principle state?
options: Every story detail must serve a purpose
